DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: ZANOTTO, E. D.;Zanotto, Edgar D.;Zanotto, Edgar Dutra;Zanotto, E.D.;Zanotto, Edgar;Edgar Dutra Zanotto;ZANOTTO, E. D;Zanotto, E;ZANOTTO, EDGAR D;ZANOTTO, ED;DUTRA ZANOTTO, EDGAR;ZANOTTO, E.;ZANOTTO, EDGAR. D.

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH:
Materials Engineer-Universidade Federal de São Carlos (1976), MSc Physics-IFSC-USP (1979), PhD Glass Tech-University of Sheffield, UK (1982). Polymers specialization-International School of Polymer Science, Ferrara, Itália, 1992. Visiting professor (Fullbright Fellow) University of Arizona (1987); University of Central Florida (2005), USA. Prof. Universidade Federal de São Carlos. 

E.D. Zanotto has received 54 science AWARDS: e.g., Comenda ONMEI 2018, Grã-Cruz medal 2018, Nanocell 2017, Admiral Álvaro Alberto 2014, Comenda Nacional Ordem Mérito Cientifico (Knight) 2006, TWAS Engineering Award 2010, and various "glass" awards. CNPq researcher 1A..

His WORK includes fundamental and applied research on crystallization kinetics and properties of glasses and glass-ceramics (GC), including rigorous tests, improvement or development of nucleation and growth models for glasses, effects of liquid phase separation on nucleation, surface crystallization kinetics, overall crystallization, glass stability, glass forming ability, molecular structure and nucleation mechanism, sintering with simultaneous crystallization, diffusion processes in glasses, as well as mechanical, rheological, thermal and bio properties of glasses and GC..The technological branch of Zanotto?s team include projects in partnership with 22 companies and consultancy to over 40 companies. He is interested in the development of glasses and GC with improved or new functionalities..

EDZ created the Vitreous Materials Lab (lamav.weebly.com) in 77. He has PUBLISHED over 330 original and review papers, 21 book chapters, 3 books, 5 book prefaces, 29 filled patents, and advised ~ 90 theses and post docs. 28 of his ex-students and post-docs became professors or glass researchers.. 

He RANKS 7th in the list of patents granted in Brazil. Regarding crystallization of oxide glasses, he is the most prolific at SCOPUS with the keywords (crystal nucleation glass). Leadership index=91%, H index = 60 (Google), <FWCI> = 1.4. Listed in the PLOS ranking of 1% most influential researchers.

EDZ is an EDITOR of the Journal of Non-Crystalline Solids, and Advisory Board Member of: Int. Mat. Reviews (Key reader), S-Nature App.Sciences, Int. J. Applied Glass Science, Papers in Physics, Materials Research, Bull. Soc. Espanhola Ceramica y Vidrio, Iranian J.M.S&T, and Cerâmica..

He is a member of both Brazilian & São Paulo State ACADEMY OF SCIENCES, National Academy of Engineering, The World Academy of Sciences (TWAS), World Academy of Ceramics, Fellow Fullbrigth, Soc. Glass Tech, American Cer. Soc., and Brazilian Cer. Soc.. Chaired 6 of the most important glass congresses, member of Scientific Advisory Board of more than 50 materials and glass congresses, delivered over 400 conference presentations, including ~160 INVITED talks and ~35 plenary talks..

His AWARDS include the most important Brazilian prize (A^3), and 7 important glass research awards (Zachariasen Award, Gottardi Prize, Morey Award, Foster Prize; Turner, Cooper, and Scholes Lecturer), Zanotto award created by MRS India..

FORMER consulting positions in academia, industry and society: Adjunct coordinator of exact sciences and engineering Fapesp; Manager of Fapesp´s Patent Office, President- Scientific Committee Serrapilheira Institute, co-founder Brazilian MRS (SBPMat), Chief editor of Materials Research (13years), Advisory Board member NSF´s IMI, TAB member O-I, USA, Chair of the Glass and Optical Materials Division Amer.Cer.Society..

CURRENT POSITIONS in BRAZIL- Director of Fapesp's CEPID-CeRTEV, President of the Council - São Carlos High Tech Park Foundation; Counselor Emeritus and Director of Brazilian Ceramic Society; Council Member of IMPA and Serrapilheira Institute, President of the I2Mat

INTERNATIONAL POSITIONS: J. Non-Crystalline Solids Editor, ICG Crystallization Committee member, ACerS Global Ambassador, Council member: Int. Ceramic Federation, Int. Commission on Glass & FunGlass Inst
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: graduation at Engenharia de Materiais from Universidade Federal de São Carlos (1976), master's at Física from Fisica Usp São Carlos (1979) and doctorate at Ceramics Glasses And Polymers from The University Of Sheffield (1982). Has experience in Material and Metallurgical Engineering, focusing on Ceramics, acting on the following subjects: vidro, cristalizacao, nucleation, glass and viscosidade.

OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES:
Edgar Dutra Zanotto concluiu seu doutorado em Tecnologia de Vidros na Universidade de Sheffield, na Inglaterra, em 1982, cuja tese foi premiada com o ?Foster Research Prize?. Em 1988 atuou como professor visitante (Fulbright Fellow) no Departamento de Ciência e Engenharia de Materiais da Universidade do Arizona, em Tucson, nos EUA. Entre setembro de 1992 e março de 1993, fez um curso de especialização na Escola Internacional de Estudos Avançados em Ciência de Polímeros na Universidade de Ferrara na Itália, cuja dissertação foi premiada com a menção ?bravíssimo?. Passou à categoria de Professor Titular de Engenharia de Materiais da UFSCar em 1993. 2005 atuou como cientista visitante no College of Optics and Photonics, na University of Central Florida, em Orlando, FL, EUA. 
As atividades de pesquisa fundamental do professor Zanotto e colaboradores focalizam principalmente o tema ?cristalização e propriedades de vidros? e foram divulgadas em aproximadamente 200 publicações, no Brasil e no exterior. As citações dos seus trabalhos são similares as de cada um dos quatro pesquisadores mais experientes e conhecidos em nível mundial na área de cristalização de vidros inorgânicos. Edgar Zanotto foi o responsável pela implantação de um dos primeiros núcleos de pesquisa brasileiros sobre materiais vítreos (LaMaV), em 1977 na UFSCar. Tal núcleo alcançou um nível de excelência e reputação internacional. O professor já orientou aproximadamente 50 mestres e doutores e 20 post-docs. Seu laboratório, LaMaV, foi reconhecido como núcleo de excelência pelo PRONEX em 1995. O Prof. Zanotto foi agraciado com 20 prêmios nacionais e seis prêmios internacionais, que incluíram 5 dos cinco prêmios mais importantes na área de vidros (Zachariasen Award, Vittorio Gottardi Prize e GW Morey award, Turner and Cooper lectu). Ele apresentou aproximadamente 100 conferências à convite em congressos nacionais e internacionais sendo 10 plenárias. As atividades de pesquisa tecnológica do Professor Zanott..

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The temperature dependece and magnitude of crystal growth rate in glass-forming liquids are of tecnological and fundamental interest. This paper discusses crystal growth data for cordierite (2MgO.2Al2O3.5SiO2) and diopside (MgO.CaO.2SiO2) growing from theri own melts. In both systems the measured crystal phases were proved to occur as the primary crystal phase in the whole temperature range. For cordierite we measured crystal growth rates of the metastable crystal phase, mu-cordierite, in a very broad temperature range from 800oC to 1350oC (Tg =815oC, the glass transition; Tm - 1467oC, the melting point). In the case of diopside we collected growth rates of the stable crystal phase, diopside, from 800 oC to 1350 oC (Tg = 722oC, Tm = 1392oC). The maximum growth rate occurs at 1250oC for mu-cordierite and at 1275oC for diopside. Both data sets show a shoulder at 1000oC. The crystal growth rate data of both glasses are discussed in terms of the standard models of crystal growth. Several possibilities to explain the shoulder are discussed

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Diopside glass reveals only surface heterogeneous nucleation. The growth rate of crystals U was measured for two special cases: the movement of the crystal/melt interface on the mechanical (Um/p, Fig. 1) or fire (Uf/p) polished surfaces and into the bulk of sample from its surface, i.e. the growth rate of the crystalline surface layer (Uc/l). The measurements of Um/p and Uf/p were performed for single crystals observation. Arrhenius plots of ln Uc/l versus 1/T show a remarkable break at 870oC, giving activation energies 692 and 487 kJ/mol for the temperature ranges 814 - 870oC and 870 - 954oC, respectively (Fig. 2), contrary to the monotonous decrease of free activation energy of viscous flow. Crystalline layer reveals two well distinguishable morphologies. The growth of the first morphology that nucleate on the external side of sample is stopped by the second one, which has the same growth rate and the same composition, according to EDS (Fig. 3)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We define an adimensional parameter that is capable of predicting if a glass powder compact can be fully densified by viscous flow sintering or if concurrent surface crystallization will hinder densification. The proposed sinterability parameter is S(T)=gama/[(Ns^0.5).U(T).eta(t).r], where gama is the glass/vapor surface energy, Ns the density of nucleation sites on the glass surface, U(T) the crystal growth rate, eta(T) the viscosity, and r the average particle size radius. For high temperatures, T>0.85Tm, where Tm is the melting point of the crystal phase, an approximate expression can be used: Sht(T)=2.PI.gama.Na.Tm^2.Vm^2/3/[10(Ns^0.5).r.DHm.DT^2], where Vm is the molar volume, Na is Avogadro s number, DHm is the melting enthalpy of the crystal phase, and DT=T-Tm is the undercooling. This expression avoids the (time consuming) measurement of U(T) and eta(T). Predictions can be made by S or ShT avoiding the need to perform any sintering experiment. We demonstrate that the condition to successfully densify any glass powder at a given temperature is S > 50 and this value is typically reached at 0.85Tm. For a given composition the physical properties are fixed (as r and NS), but higher temperatures and smaller particle sizes always increase S and privilege sintering over surface crystallization (Fig. 1, density >99%). This new parameter is a useful aid for the development of sintered glasses and glass-ceramics (see Fig. 2, based on experimental data)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We collected and analyzed extensive literature data on crystal growth rates and viscosity in the temperature range between the glass transition, Tg, and the melting point, Tm, of some stoichiometric silicates, such as SiO2, Li2O.2SiO2, Li2O.3SiO2, Na2O.2SiO2, Na2O.3SiO2, CaO.MgO.2SiO2, CaO.Al2O3.2SiO2, PbO.SiO2. We then calculated effective diffusion coefficients from experimental crystal growth rates, Du, using classical models, and from viscosity, Deta , through the Eyring equation. Finally we compared these two independent diffusivities with directly measured self-diffusion coefficients of the slowest species, silicon and oxygen, DSi and DO, respectively. Our results show that: i) In the neighborhood of Tm, for CaO.MgO.2SiO2 DSi =DO = Du = Deta. Silicon self-diffusion data were also available for Na2O.2SiO2, Na2O.3SiO2, and PbO.SiO2 and, for these systems DSi = Du = Deta. For the other four systems Du = Deta. Summarizing, Du = Deta for all nine systems, and they are similar to DSi and DO for all those systems for which such data are available. ii) Between Tm and Td = 1.2Tg (the decoupling temperature), Du = Deta for all nine systems. In addition DO = Du = Deta in soda-lime-silica, but not in pure silica. For silica, DSi = Du = Deta but different from DO. iii) Below Td =1.2 Tg, Du is differente from Deta for four systems for which crystal growth rate data were available (Li2O.2SiO2, CaO.Al2O3.2SiO2, PbO.SiO2 and soda-lime-silica). For PbO.SiO2, silicon self-diffusion strongly differs from Deta. For Li2O.2SiO2 and CaO.Al2O3.2SiO2 , Du differs from Deta and from DO. For soda-lime-silica DO differs from Deta at a single temperature. For silica glass DSi = Deta and differs from DO. The fitted jump distance lambda in the crystal growth equation was about 1 for all systems. Some, but not all, systems show a sign of a breakdown in the Stokes-Einsten/ Eyring equation at Td > Tg. This study unveils the transport mechanism in some glass forming systems and validates the u

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Lithium borates are of great scientific interest because it is one of the few oxide systems that display homogeneous nucleation. Despite this fact its crystallization kinetics have been poorly investigated so far. We present here the first observations of two kinds of crystals in di-lithium tetra borate glass, and some measurements of their crystallization kinetics. Three different cooling rates, from 10 to about 1000 K/s, were employed to obtain glasses with different frozen entropy states. The densities of these glasses correspond to distinct fictive temperatures, estimated to be between 495 and 693oC, which exceed the normal (laboratory time scale) glass transition temperature, Tg ~ 490oC, estimated from DSC curves at ~0.2 K/s. Two different crystal morphologies were observed in these glasses: one opaque, more or less isometric, poorly defined crystals (type 1) formed on the glass surfaces and in its interior; and transparent crystals with regular rectangular parallelepiped or ellipsoid shape (type 2), which nucleated only in the glass interior. The nucleation rate of type 2 crystals is moderate and exceeds that of the type 1 crystals by about 2 orders of magnitude. The growth rate of the former strongly exceeds the growth rate of the type 2 crystals. Since the reduced glass transition temperature, Tgr=Tg/Tm (Tm = liquidus), of lithium tetra borate glass is about 0.6, only weak homogeneous volume nucleation rates are expected for this glass. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the type 2 crystals are some metastable phase with relative high nucleation and low growth rates. The formation of two crystalline phases was corroborated by NMR analyses, which showed different molecular structures for glasses prepared with different cooling rates. The fact that a glass with higher fictive temperature (lower density) reveals higher nucleation rate is of special interest

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Recently iron phosphate glasses have been receiving increasing attention as a host for nuclear waste materials. Phosphate glasses of composition (100-z-x)FeO.xFe2O3.zP2O5 with z = 60 and 66.67 mol % were prepared in this research. The phosphorous and iron oxide components were verified by X-ray fluorescence analysis and the amounts of FeO and Fe2O3 were determined by Mössbauer spectroscopy. Thermal characterization was performed by dilatometry (DTA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) to obtain Tg (the glass transition), Td (the dilatometric softening), Tx (the onset crystallization), Tp (the crystallization peak) and Tm (the melting point) characteristics temperatures. As far as we know, for the first time viscosity measurements were performed in such systems using the micropenetration (MP) and the hot stage microscopy (HSM) techniques in a wide temperature range (from near Tg to Tm). In particular, using HSM it was possible to characterize the deformation, softening, half-ball and melting points. Good reproducibility was observed using both viscosity techniques. Using these viscosity results we adjusted Vogel-Fulcher-Tammann-Hesse (VFTH) curves, calculated the activation energies for viscous flow E(T), and assessed the fragility parameters m and D. In particular, comparison between DTA and MP characteristics temperatures resulted in similar values for Tg and Td

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Based on the Johnson-Mehl-Avrami-Kolmogorov (JMAK) theory, we propose two new models to describe the crystallization kinetics of glass particles and use them to determinate the density of nucleation sites, Ns, on glass powders. We test these models with sintered compacts of diopside glass particles using sinter-crystallization treatments at 825 C (Tg~727 C), that covered from null to almost 100% crystallized volume fraction. We measured and compared the evolution of the crystallized volume fractions by optical microscopy and X-ray diffraction. Then we fit our expressions to experimental data using Ns and R (the average particle radius) as adjustable parameters. For comparison, we also fit to our data existing expressions that describe the crystallized volume fraction in glass powders. We demonstrate that all the methods allow one to estimate Ns with reasonable accuracy. For our ground and water-washed diopside glass powder, Ns is between 10^10 - 10^11 sites/m2. The reasonable agreement between experimental and adjusted R confirms the consistency of all these methods. For one of our equations one does not need to deal with the change of crystallization mechanism from 3-dimension to 1-dimension mode Apresentacao ORAL

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Crystal growth rates in PbO-SiO2 glass have been determined in a wide temperature range between 480oC (Tg=400oC) to about 725oC (Tm=764oC). The experimental values are within one order of magnitude of the theoretically-predicted curve based on the 2D surface nucleation growth model. We also analyzed literature data on viscosity (eta) and diffusivities of lead and silicon (DPb and DSi) at deep and low undercoolings. The effective diffusivity for viscous flow, Deta, and its controlling activation energy were compared with the activation energies and diffusivities calculated from crystal growth rates, Du , and with DPb and DSi. Between the melting point and Td= 500oC (where eta = 4x10^6 Pa.s), Du=Deta=DPb=DSi, while for higher viscosities the silicon and lead diffusivities are still similar but higher than Deta and Du. Therefore, below Td there is clear decoupling between cationic diffusivity and diffusivity calculated from isostructural and equilibrium viscosity, and diffusivity calculated from crystal growth rates, i.e. (Du=Deta)<(DSi=DPb). Hence, only above 500oC silicon and lead control the transport mechanism involved in crystal growth and viscous flow

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We collected extensive literature data and combined with our own data on crystal growth rates, induction times for nucleation, and viscosity of lithium disilicate (Li2O.2SiO2) glass from very low to deep undercoolings [from 0.99Tm to 0.54Tm (= 0.98Tg)], where Tm=1307 K is the melting point and Tg=727 K is the DSC glass transition temperature. We took into account the meltcrystal interface temperatures, which are slightly increased due to the release of heat of crystallization and tested the classical models of crystal growth. The best fit was obtained for growth mediated by screw dislocations as the operative mechanism in a wide range of temperatures. The only adjustable parameter, lambda = 1.3 angstrom , has the expected order of magnitude of the jump distance. Effective diffusion coefficients were calculated from induction times for nucleation, crystal growth rates, and from viscosity (via the Eyring equation) and were compared with measured diffusion coefficients of O^2- and Li^+. We found a clear breakdown of the Stokes-Einstein/ Eyring equation at Td= 1.09Tg (viscosity eta= 4.3x10^6 Pa.s). This study validates the use of viscosity (through the Stokes-Einstein / Eyring equation) to account for the kinetic term of the crystal growth expression in a range of temperatures only above Td. INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We analysed extensive data on crystal growth rates, induction times for nucleation, and viscosity of lithium disilicate (Li2O-2SiO2) glass from very low to deep undercoolings. The best fit was obtained for growth mediated by screw dislocations as the operative mechanism in a wide range of temperatures. The only adjustable parameter, l ~ 1 , has the expected order of magnitude of the jump distance. Effective diffusion coefficients were calculated from induction times for nucleation, crystal growth rates, and from viscosity (via the Eyring equation) and were compared with measured diffusion coefficients of O and Li. We found a clear breakdown of the Stokes-Einstein/ Eyring equation at Td ~ 1.09Tg (viscosity ~ 4.3 x 10^8 Pas). This study validates the use of viscosity (through the Stokes-Einstein/ Eyring equation) to account for the kinetic term of the crystal growth expression in a range of temperatures only above Td. INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Diopside glass reveals only surface (or heteregeneous) crystallization. Three different surface treatments were used to analyze the crystal growth rate temperature dependence considering the same batch: mechanical polished, fire polished (for single crystals observations) and crystal layer (between 800 and 954oC, Tg = 722oC). Arrhenius plots of ln u versus 1/T in this range showed a remarkable break at 870oC, giving different activation energies for crystal growth Eu (ln u = A Eu/RT: 487kJ/mol between 870 - 954oC and 692kJ/mol between 800 - 870oC). Such results can be explained due the tremendous increasing on viscous flow with decreasing T in such narrow interval. Most intriguing, two different regular crystal morphologies were observed by optical and electron microscopies, that grows linearly in all observations. These regular forms are typical from initial stage crystallization. Growth of crystals nucleated on the external side of sample is stopped by the formation of next well-oriented crystals morphology. Composition of both morphologies were done in crystal layers using SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy) with EDS (Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy), as also the structure of such different morphologies by X-Ray, giving the same results. For the EDS experiment we based the composition on the glass surface, comparing with the two crystal fronts. Hence, there is only one composition involved on each morphology, i.e., there is no metastable phase, just a texture of the crystal layer

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: In this study we report systematic optical microscopy measurements of the microstructure crystal growth mechanism in Li2B4O7 glass above and below the glass transition temperature, Tg = 490oC, and compare the crystallization kinetics with previous results. Chemical analysis was performed using ICP technique to ensure the correct composition of this system (17.37Li2O-82.63B2O3 wt%), that presents a high homogeneous (or volume) nucleation rate (1.6x10^8 m-3s-1 at the maximum) and also one of the highest maximum crystal growth rates measured (177 micron/min). We have measured the crystal growth rate between 420 and 540oC in a fire polished surface and compared with two previous mechanical polished surface results, i.e., individual crystals and also crystal growth layers. It has been determined that the crystals grow linearly with time in all experiments. Results using fire polished surfaces showed a higher crystal growth rate, probably due to absence of usual defects in mechanical polished surfaces. Arrhenius plots of ln u versus 1/T presented a break at 480oC, showing an increasing on the activation energy for crystal growth Eu below this temperature. The explanation for such result is due to a drastic change on the viscous flow behavior, from a transition of Vogel-Fulcher-Tammann-Hesse (VFTH) at higher temperatures to the iso-structural state below Tg. INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The maximum homogeneous nucleation rates, Imax, of silicate glasses strongly diminish with the reduced glass transition temperature, Tgr (= Tg=Tm/L, where Tg is the glass transition temperature and Tm/L is the melting point or liquidus temperature), as recent publications demonstrated. In addition, the critical cooling rates for metallic glass formation, qcr, also drop with rising Tgr. From these empirical observations as well as from theoretical considerations, it is expected that the maximum crystal growth rates, Umax, also depend on Tgr. In this work we test and confirm this assumption by plotting experimental Umax vs. Tgr for 31 silicate glasses, and then use the most common crystal growth model - screw dislocation - to calculate and compare maximum experimental growth rates with theoretical predictions. Despite several assumptions made for the calculations, there is good agreement between theory and experiment, both in the magnitude of Umax(Tgr) and in the temperature of the maximum crystal growth rate, TUmax. These findings indicate that the screw dislocation growth model is a good approximation to describe crystal growth in silicate glasses. Apresentacao ORAL

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Glass-forming ability (GFA) is the easiness to vitrify a liquid on cooling, while glass stability (GS) is the glass resistance against devitri cation on heating; but it is questionable if there is any direct relationship between these two parameters. Therefore, to test this possibility, we assess and compare GFA and several GS parameters through quantitative criteria. GFA and GS were calculated for six stoichiometric glass forming oxides that only present surface (heterogeneous) crystallization in laboratory time scales: GeO2, Na2O 2SiO2, PbO SiO2, CaO Al2O3 2SiO2, CaO MgO 2SiO2 and 2MgO 2Al2O3 5SiO2; plus Li2O 2SiO2 and Li2O 2B2O3 that, in addition to surface nucleation, also present homogeneous (internal) crystallization. We gauge GFA by the critical cooling rate, qcr, which was calculated from an estimated number of heterogeneous nucleation sites per unit surface, Ns, and from experimental crystal growth rates, U(T), assuming a detectable surface crystallized fraction Xc = 0:001. We de ne GS parameters by fourteen di erent combinations of the following characteristic di erential thermal analysis (DTA) or di erential scanning calorimetry (DSC) temperatures: the glass transition temperature (Tg), the onset crystallization temperature on heating Thx , the peak crystallization temperature on heating Thc , and the melting point (Tm). To obtain the experimental GS parameters for each glass we carried out DSC runs using coarse and ne powders, and completed the necessary data with literature values for Tm. The results for ne and coarse particles were quite similar. Most of the GS parameters that consist of three characteristic DSC temperatures show excellent correlation with GFA, however, rather poor correlations were observed for parameters that use only two characteristic temperatures. We thus demonstrated that certain, but not all GS parameters can be used infer GFA. Apresentacao ORAL

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We collected and analyzed extensive literature data on crystal growth rate and viscosity in the temperature range between the glass transition, Tg, and the melting point, Tm, of some silicates, such as SiO2, Li2O 2SiO2, Li2O 3SiO2, Na2O 2SiO2, Na2O 3SiO2, CaO MgO 2SiO2, CaO Al2O3 2SiO2, PbO SiO2, and commercial Na2O-CaO-SiO2 glass. We then calculated effective diffusion coefficients from experimental crystal growth rates, Du, using classical models, and from viscosity, D through the Eyring equation. We compared these two independent diffusivities with directly measured self-diffusion coefficients of the slowest species, silicon and oxygen, DSi and DO, respectively. The results clearly show that:i) In the neighborhood of Tm, for CaO MgO 2SiO2 and soda-lime-silica, DSi DO = Du = D . Silicon self-diffusion data were also available for Na2O 2SiO2, Na2O 3SiO2, and PbO SiO2 and DSi Du = D . For the other four systems Du = D . Summarizing, Du = D for all nine systems, and they are similar to DSi and DO for those systems for which such data are available. ii) Between Tm and Td 1.2Tg (the decoupling temperature), Du = D for all nine systems. In addition DO Du = D in soda-lime-silica, but not in pure silica. For silica, DSi = Du = D DO. iii) Below Td 1.2 Tg, Du D for four systems for which crystal growth rate data were available (Li2O 2SiO2, CaO Al2O3 2SiO2, PbO SiO2 and soda-lime-silica). For PbO SiO2, silicon self-diffusion strongly differs from D . For Li2O 2SiO2 and CaO Al2O3 2SiO2 , Du D DO. For soda-lime-silica DO D at a single temperature. For silica glass DSi = D DO. The fitted jump distance used in the crystal growth equation was consistently about 1 for all systems. Du could be viewed as an effective diffusion coefficient of structural unities in crystal growth. It seems to be a good parameter to assess decoupling phenomenon due to more feasible measurement than direct ionic diffusion. Apresentacao ORAL

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We collected and critically analyzed literature data on crystal growth rate, viscosity and self-diffusion coefficients between the glass transition range, Tg, and the melting point, Tm, for four types of commercial silica glasses. Our analysis demonstrates that the crystal growth rates, viscosities and self-diffusion coefficients of this especial network glass are extremely dependent on the impurity level, much more than for multi-component silicate glasses. Combining such kinetic data at deep and low undercoolings we confirmed normal growth as the operative mechanism of crystal growth. Comparisons of calculated diffusivities for crystal growth, calculated from viscous flow, and directly measured silicon and oxygen diffusivities for each silica type were also performed. The results demonstrate that silicon is the controlling element of the effective transport mechanism involved in crystal growth and viscous flow in silica glass. Apresentacao ORAL

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We analyzed extensive literature data on crystal growth rate, u, viscosity, eta, and diffusivities of silicon and oxygen at deep and low undercoolings, between the glass transition, Tg, and the melting point, Tm, for four types of commercial silica glasses and thin films. The self-diffusion coefficients plus u and eta in this network glass are extremely dependent on the impurity level, much more than in multi-component, depolymerized, silicate glasses. Despite this drawback, we combined such kinetic data in a systematic way and confirmed that normal growth is the operative mechanism of crystal growth. The effective diffusivities, Deta, and respective activation energies for viscous flow were compared with the activation energies and diffusivities calculated from crystal growth rates, Du, and with those of silicon and oxygen diffusion rates. We conclude that silicon (not oxygen) controls the transport mechanism involved in crystal growth and viscous flow in this glass. The congruence of Du and Deta indicates that, whatever the bond breaking and molecular reorientation mechanism required for crystallization is, it is the same as that required for the atomic transport mechanism that controls viscous flow. We thus conclude that viscosity data can be used to estimate the transport part that controls crystal growth in this glass from the melting point to about Tg Apresentacao ORAL

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: On cooling any liquid from the equilibrium temperature, spontaneous crystallization frequently impairs glass formation. On the other hand, controlled crystallization of certain glasses may lead to unusual glass-ceramics having a plethora of interesting properties and applications. However, key questions regarding diffusion, viscous flow and crystal growth kinetics in glasses are still open. For instance, which ions or "molecular units" move collectively above Tg (the glass transition temperature) and control these important phenomena? Is the (often used) viscosity coefficient capable of describing molecular transport at the crystal/liquid interface? Silica (SiO2) is an important mineral from the geological standpoint, is the most important glass former, and also have a plethora of important commercial applications, such as laboratory glassware, telescopic mirrors, optical filters and fibers. The crystal growth rates and viscosities of silica glass are extremely dependent on the impurity level, much more than in multi-component silicate glasses. In this work all these details are analyzed. We collected and compared literature data on crystal growth rate and viscosity in the temperature range between 1.2Tg and the melting point of silica. We found that the normal growth model describes quite well the experimental growth rate data in this wide temperature range. Then we calculated effective diffusion coefficients from crystal growth rates, Du, and from viscosity, Dh (through the Eyring equation), and compared these two independent diffusivities with measured self-diffusion coefficients of silicon and oxygen. The results show that silicon controls the diffusion dynamics involved in crystal growth and viscous flow. This study not only unveils the transport mechanism in this glass, but also validates the use of viscosity to account for the transport term of the crystal growth expression in a wide range of undercoolings. Apresentacao ORAL

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-2: Atividades No Campo das Nanotecnologias e Desenvolvimento de Nanoprodutos
SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-3: Fabricação de Produtos de Minerais Não-Metálicos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The density of nucleation sites on glass particle surfaces is a key parameter for the simulation of the sintering kinetics with concurrent crystallization, but its direct determination for powders is quite difficult. To measure the site density on glass surfaces one traditionally uses a microscope to count the number of crystals in a determined area as a function of time and temperature after thermal treatments above Tg (the transformation temperature). However, when dealing with glass powders, this method is not applicable because it is not practical to heat-treat particles having submillimeter diameters and to count crystals on their uneven surfaces. The extrapolation of results using larger samples to powders is not suitable, because the rate of heterogeneous nucleation on glass surfaces strongly depends on the surface state, which in turn depends on the way the powder is prepared. In searching for a practical method to estimate the nuclei density for glasses, in this study we used a glass having the composition of diopside (MgO.CaO.2SiO2), prepared different sets of particles having almost monomodal diameters, using the same grinding technique, and compacted them into a mold. The compacts were isothermally treated for sintering and simultaneous crystallization at different temperatures and times. Sections of such samples were prepared for microscopy and the crystallized fractions were determined. Using reliable literature data of crystal growth rate in diopside glass and the measured crystallized fractions we estimated the surface nuclei density by the Johnson-Mehl-Avrami-Kolmogorov equation. The results were compared with those obtained from X-ray diffraction and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Recent publications demonstrate that the maximum homogeneous nucleation rates, Imax, of 55 silicate glasses strongly diminish with the reduced glass transition temperature, Tgr (= Tg/Tm/L, where Tg is the glass transition temperature and Tm/L is the melting point or liquidus temperature). In addition, the critical cooling rates for metallic glass formation, Rc, also drop with rising Tgr. From these empirical observations as well as from theoretical considerations, it is expected that the maximum crystal growth rates, Umax, also depend on Tgr. In this work we present results that confirm these assumptions by plotting experimental Umax vs. Tgr for 20 silicate glasses, and then use the most common crystal growth model screw dislocation growth to calculate and compare maximum experimental growth rates with theoretical predictions. Despite several assumptions made for the calculations, there is good agreement between theory and experiment, both in the magnitude of Umax(Tgr) and in the temperature of the maximum crystal growth rate, TmaxU Apresentacao Oral dia 14/11/2005 às 11:50h

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-3: Fabricação de Produtos de Minerais Não-Metálicos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Growth rates of fresnoite crystals (2BaO.T iO2.2SiO2) in fresnoite glass were measured as a function of temperature in a wide temperature range (0.56-0.60Tm and 0.87-0.93Tm). Combining these growth rate data, the applicability of standard models of crystal growth was tested in the range Tg<T<Tm (Tg is the glass transition temperature and Tm is the melting point). For low undercoolings the reduced growth rate curve is suggestive of either screw dislocation or 2D surface nucleation growth. However, a more detailed analysis of the growth rate plot indicates that the operative crystal growth mechanism might be screw dislocation. The maximum experimental growth rate is 430 micron/s at 1260oC. Viscosity as a function of temperature was also measured in the same glass and a wide temperature range (near Tg to Tm), and follows a Vogel-Fulcher-Tamman (VFT) form. Effective diffusivities Deff were calculated both from crystal growth and viscosity data, and the results compared to verify the validity of Stokes-Einstein equation

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-3: Fabricação de Produtos de Minerais Não-Metálicos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: We collected extensive literature data on viscosity and crystal growth kinetics in diopside (CaO.MgO.2SiO2) glasses in a wide temperature range between 1.1Tg (the glass transition temperature) and 0.99Tm (the melting point). To these we added our own data. Combining viscosities and crystal growth rates at deep (0.64-0.86Tm) and low undercoolings (0.93-0.99Tm), we tested the classical crystal growth models. Our results confirm growth mediated by screw dislocations as the operative mechanism in this system in a wide temperature range. Effective diffusion coeffcients were calculated directly from crystal growth rates and from viscosity (using the Stokes-Einstein equation), and were compared with measured diffusion coeffcients of silicon and oxygen in diopside melt. We conclude that silicon and oxygen move together and control the diffusion mechanism involved in crystal growth and viscous flow in this glass. This study unveils the diffusion mechanism in liquid diopside and validates the use of viscosity to account for the kinetic term of the crystal growth expression in a wide temperature range. Ongoing studies may confirm (or not) if this remarkable finding about the diffusion mechanism also applies for other silicate glasses

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Glass-in-glass or liquid-liquid phase separation (PS) is a common phenomenon in multicomponent systems. Researches dealing with glass-ceramics in the 1960s and 70s were keenly interested in the thermodynamics and kinetics of PS. Later on, scientists working on polymer blends focused on the same problem. More recently, after the discovery of bulk metallic glasses, this community also turned its attention to the possible effects of phase separation on the course and kinetics of crystallization of complex alloys. In this talk, we critically review some systematic research work undertaken on pseudo binary glass-forming liquids with the purpose of shedding light on details of the often-observed effects of PS on crystallization. Detailled small-angle X-ray scattering, transmission electron microscopy and optical microscopy studies have been conducted involving the kinetics and morphology of simultaneous phase separation and crystal nucleation in highly supercooled baria-silica and lithia-silica glasses. No correlation has been found between the PS surface area and crystal nucleation in these systems; hence, no evidence of heterogeneous crystal nucleation on the liquid phase interfaces has been detected. These studies have shown that the main effect of PS is to cause compositional shifts that play an important role in the pahtways of crystallization, and particularly in the kinetics of nucleation. Explanations are given for these findings. Apresentação ORAL

REGISTRO-OU-PATENTE.INSTITUICAO-DEPOSITO-REGISTRO: INPI - Instituto Nacional da Propriedade Industrial
REGISTRO-OU-PATENTE.NOME-DO-DEPOSITANTE: Ana C M Rodrigues;FILHO, OSCAR PEITL;SOUZA, MARINA;Universidade Federal de São Carlos

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Refere-se ao processo de produção de enxertos ósseos obtidos apartir da manufatura aditiva, especificamente impressão 3D, de umacomposição em pó, desenvolvida para possibilitar a adaptação doequipamento para a fabricação de peças de biovidro F18 (4), aoinvés de gesso, tradicionalmente utilizado. Para tanto, o processo seinicia com a obtenção (E1-E7) do pó de biovidro F18 (4), seguida desua mistura (E8) com os demais componentes (C2) dos enxertos:maltodextrina, acetato de magnésio, carboximetil-celulose, hidróxidode cálcio, fosfato de tricálcio-ß e fosfato dibásico de potássio; amistura (M), após inserida (E9) na impressora 3D, passa por etapasde secagem (E10, E12 e E13), tanto no interior, quanto fora doequipamento, antes de suas etapas de queima (E15-E18), sendo osscaffolds obtidos (SO); esses ainda podem ser infiltrados (E19-E24)com uma solução de colágeno e partículas de biovidro F18 (CB), afim de aumentar ainda mais sua resistência mecânica. Os scaffoldsobtidos por meio do processo propostos, infiltrados (SI) ou não (SO)apresentam resistência e porosidade altas, quando comparados aoestado da técnica e podem ser aplicados em odontologia, ortopediae medicina veterinária
